questions.questionText: Some drivers believe that vehicle safety features allow them to pay less attention when they drive - is this a correct way of thinking?
questions.info: Many Canadian drivers believe that having safety features on their vehicle makes it less dangerous to drive while distracted. A concerning 19.2% of drivers reported that they would be likely to drive while distracted if their vehicle was equipped with modern safety features. Drivers who believe that safety features compensate for safe driving place themselves and other road users at a higher risk of a collision.

options.text: Yes and some vehicles even drive themselves - sit back and relax as the vehicle is certain to let us know when there is a problem for us to solve.

No as that is very dangerous thinking - driving takes a significant amount of mental concentration and activities that diminish a driver’s ability to focus on driving and road conditions increase the risk of a collision regardless of the safety features in the vehicle.

questions.questionText: Is it true that with the current level of vehicle technology, new drivers don't have to worry about their lack of experience?
questions.info: In particular, it takes time for new drivers to develop a sense of situational awareness. This refers to the driver’s ability to get the ‘big picture’ of what is going on around them. It involves keeping an eye on other drivers and the road, anticipating future events and identifying potentially hazardous situations quickly.

options.text: Yes - newer vehicle technologies make driving much easier, such as not having to check blind spots when changing lanes or turning since vehicles have blind spot indicators and there is no worry about backing up because there are cameras.

No, as young and new drivers have a higher collision risk than all other age groups and vehicle safety technologies may not protect them from a lack of driving experience. Driving is a complex task that requires visual, manual and cognitive skills.

questions.questionText: Do you agree that the best hand position is '9 and 3'?

options.text: Yes since that is what I read online and some high-performance race vehicle courses say that it's the best.

No - the best hand position is '10 and 2' for the average driver on regular roads because it allows for smooth hand-over-hand steering and keeps the vehicle under control at all times and in all conditions. (Racing vehicles have smaller steering wheels so that the driver can turn the wheel and never take their hands off, which is necessary at the high speeds they drive.)

questions.questionText: Is it true that if you're driving a vehicle with an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS), the right method to stop the vehicle on a slippery surface in an emergency is to pump the brakes?

options.text: Yes, that's what my family taught me who have many years of driving experience and surely must be right.

No, that is incorrect because when driving a vehicle equipped with ABS, the driver needs to slam the brake pedal to the floor and keep it there. (The pedal pulsations and noises are normal as the ABS system engages and will bring the vehicle to a safe stop.)

questions.questionText: Do you agree that if you set up your outside sideview mirrors a certain way, they'll eliminate the blind spots and therefore the need to turn your head to check them?

options.text: Yes since the outside sideview mirrors can be manipulated to increase your vision to see more lanes beside you and reveal what would be in your blind spots. Turning your head for shoulder checks is very dangerous and drivers should never take their eyes off the road.

No, as adjusting the outside sideview mirrors only creates different blind spots and risks. The outside mirrors help the driver spot cyclists and motorcycles that are much smaller and harder to see coming up on the side of a vehicle. If the mirrors are turned out from the vehicle, you would never see these risks coming, including danger coming from behind.

questions.questionText: In the winter, when roads are snow-covered, is it better to let the air out of your tires to make them softer to help grip the road?

options.text: Yes, because when you underinflate a tire, it sags, letting more of the tire touch the road.

No, this is not the best tactic. Depending on the depth of the snow or surface you're driving on, properly inflated tires can sometimes dig through the surface to the pavement below while wider underinflated tires ride only on the surface of the snow.  The tire patch in the tire centre may start to lose contact with the road as the weight of the vehicle presses down with the tire centre starting to curl inwards as the tire loses more and more air. Underinflation is also damaging to the tires and wheels.

questions.questionText: When stopping at a red light, have you left enough space for the vehicle in front as long as you can see their back tires?

options.text: Yes, there is more than enough room to steer around them if they stall or have a problem.

No, that may not be sufficient space. That logic comes from a time in the past when vehicles used to have a much longer front end than they do now. Secondly, since the most common collision is the rear-end collision, if you have more room to maneuver, you increase your chances of being able to escape a collision from behind.

If you intend to turn shortly after a street, activate your signal later or reduce your speed later to avoid confusion

questions.questionText: Choose the three reasons another driver might flash their headlights at you.

options.text: Flashing their headlights at an intersection could mean the driver is giving up the right-of-way
Someone might flash their high beams to warn the driver behind them to stop
An oncoming vehicle may flash their headlights to warn of a problem ahead
Flashing their headlights can indicate that I have my high beams on
Someone might flash their high beams to tell you about the lane markings

questions.questionText: Can you signal a right turn, left turn or indicate you are stopping using hand and arm signals?

options.text: Yes - arm and hand signals can replace turn signals or even brake lights.  The key is to make them as obvious as possible as they are not as noticeable
No - Arm and hand signals would make no sense to other drivers and are only for cyclists

questions.questionText: When lane changing, what responses must you look for after you have signalled?

options.text: The vehicle in the next lane behind you should honk
The vehicle in the next lane behind you should speed up
The vehicle in the next lane behind you should maintain or reduce speed

questions.questionText: In heavy traffic, when should you activate the turn signal?

options.text: Signal when the drivers in the next lane leave enough space for you to enter safely
You don't need to signal when changing lanes - honk, start to move over and take the right-of-way
Turn the signal on early in heavy traffic to ask drivers who are following closely to stay where they are or ease back

questions.questionText: Is it fine to wave a pedestrian to go?

options.text: Yes as pedestrians are responsible for themselves and their choices

Be careful when waving someone on. If a pedestrian is a minor, you are taking legal responsibility for them and if they walk out and are hit by a vehicle, you could be legally implicated in the collision
Yes as you are only trying to help

questions.questionText: When do you cancel your signal during a lane change?

options.text: Cancel the signal once you're fully in the new lane
Cancel your signal half way through the lane change
You don't need to signal during a lane change

questions.questionText: Why do you cancel your signal ?

options.text: If you leave your signal on for too long, it may confuse other drivers as to your intentions
If you leave your signal on for too long, the signal arm will break off
If you leave your signal on for too long, the light bulb will burn out

questions.questionText: When would you use hazard lights?

options.text: Hazard lights are to help you see better in fog and white out conditions
Hazard lights indicate that your vehicle is a hazard to be noticed - the vehicle could be stopped or moving at a slower pace than the other traffic and/or have mechanical problems
Hazard lights are to communicate you're having a party inside the vehicle

questions.questionText: Should you use your turn signal to indicate that you intend to stay stopped at the side of a road?

options.text: Yes, there is no problem as you are using something to communicate your intentions
No, as turn signals mean that you are going to do something and since you are not moving, the indicator should be turned off
Yes, it is fine to leave them on so it's clear to other drivers that you intend to stay there for a while

questions.questionText: What does creeping forward communicate at intersections with traffic lights and all-way stops?

options.text: Creeping can indicate that you want to enforce your right-of-way and make other drivers stop
Creeping can indicate that your brakes are failing and that you need other drivers to understand that your vehicle is not under control and they need to get out of your way

Creeping can indicate to drivers approaching our intention to turn at an intersection when the light has turned amber.  This also works at an all-way stop (after stopping) to show drivers you should be given the right-of-way - others should ground view

questions.questionText: Besides signalling in advance, how many other ways do you communicate to warn people effectively of your intention to parallel park?

options.text: Using the brake lights
Using hand signals to encourage drivers to go around
Using the white reverse lights
All of these answers are correct

questions.questionText: Why would someone rear-end another vehicle?

options.text: Distracted driving
Driving too fast
Poor brakes
All of these answers could be correct

questions.questionText: Where should drivers be looking to avoid being rear-ended?

options.text: The vehicle's navigation system
The speedometer
The mirrors
The passenger seat

questions.questionText: If drivers keep an escape route in front of their vehicles and check their mirrors, could they possibly avoid a rear-end collision?

options.text: Yes
No

questions.questionText: Why is rear-end collision the most commonly reported collision?

options.text: Some drivers follow too closely
Some drivers are not looking well ahead
Some drivers are distracted
All of these answers could be correct

questions.questionText: How can you avoid colliding with a driver slowing or stopped in front of you?

options.text: Look well ahead and anticipate traffic slowing
Stay focused on driving and minimize distractions
Keep a safe following distance
All of these answers are correct

questions.questionText: Why does having your full lighting system on during the day lower your chance of having a collision?

options.text: It makes no difference at all since the lights are hard to see and are barely different from the normal daytime running lights.

Having full low beams on in daylight helps other drivers see your vehicle better and see you earlier, allowing them to often judge your speed more accurately to know they can safely move in front of you during a turn or lane change
Having your full high beams on can help you see better in the daylight as they will illuminate everything in front of the vehicle

questions.questionText: Some drivers rely on their automatic lights to come on when it starts to get dark - why can this be a dangerous action?

options.text: There is no danger at all as the automatic lights are a safety feature that always works

In some vehicles, the automatic lights feature does not turn on the taillights of their vehicle and the driver may be unaware of this as they can tell their front lights are on, but have no idea that their tail lights are off

questions.questionText: If you find yourself in heavy traffic and it's impossible to get a stagger, what should you do to lower your risk of a collision?

options.text: Honk at the drivers around you to let them know you're there
Start drifting towards one side of your lane to encourage those drivers to give you more space
Leave more space in front
Get as close as you can to the vehicle in front of you so no one can cut in front of you

questions.questionText: Why should you wait for two open lanes before turning onto a multi-lane street?

options.text: A vehicle that is approaching in the second lane may decide to make a lane change as you start your turn, causing a potential collision
There is no problem with turning as long as the first lane is clear and you are not impeding traffic - if someone does change lanes as you turn, it's their fault because you have the right-of-way.

questions.questionText: Why should you care if there is a vehicle in your blind spot if you do not plan to make a lane change anytime soon?

options.text: If I allow a vehicle to stay in my blind spot then I lose my escape route should I need it suddenly
There is no reason to worry about a vehicle being in my blind spot as it happens all the time, totally unavoidable and it's not like they are going to just drive into the side of my vehicle

questions.questionText: If you're passing through the blind spot of another driver, why should you cover the horn and ground view?

options.text: You want to be prepared in case the driver starts to wander unintentionally or is making a lane change and does not know you are there. By ground viewing the front tire, you can tell when they are starting to move and by covering the horn you can honk, asking them to back off more quickly.

You should cover the horn and ground view because the driver might move away from you and you need to be ready for that. They may collide into a vehicle on the other side of the road and that could start a chain reaction involving you.
You don't need to cover the horn and ground view every vehicle's blind spot you go through, only for larger vehicles because they can do more damage.

questions.questionText: What colour are the lights of most vehicles when the driver puts their vehicle into reverse?

options.text: White
Red
Blue
Yellow

questions.questionText: If you are turning with an advance arrow or protected turn and a pedestrian has started to cross illegally towards where you're going to turn, what should you do?

options.text: Tap the horn, cover the brake and wait to see if the communication was received by the pedestrian.  If they stop a safe distance away, complete your turn if there is time.
Tap the horn and continue moving quickly. You need to make it clear to the pedestrian that they are in the wrong and you have the right-of-way - they will get the message and get out of your way.
Speed up to try and make the turn before they get in your path - you cannot impede the traffic behind you as they will honk at you if you don't go
Roll down your window and yell at the pedestrian to stop them from crossing

questions.questionText: If I leave extra space between my vehicle and the white stop line, won't other drivers be really annoyed with me?

options.text: If doing the Control sub-habit correctly, the drivers behind will rarely have much reaction at all. Remember, when vehicles approach from behind, you will be moving up and as you move up, the drivers behind are looking at a red light and will settle in waiting for it to change.
Leaving that extra space is not necessary as nobody does it and doing so may cause road rage incidents behind you

questions.questionText: Which are the two main things you need to avoid a rear collision?

options.text: Drive a large vehicle so you don't need to worry about avoiding a rear collision
Fast reflexes and space to drive into
Knowledge that the danger is coming from behind and the space to move away from it
Knowledge that the danger is coming from behind and race car driver skills to handle the vehicle

Control
Scan

questions.questionText: I (Driver A) was stopped for almost thirty seconds waiting for the traffic light to change when I heard the screech of tires behind me. Left Centre Right, Ground View, Minimum Eye Lead Time

questions.questionText: I (Driver A) was driving in the middle of a pack of vehicles on a one-way street. I was cut off by Driver B who swerved to avoid a vehicle door being opened in the curb lane. I hit Driver B's left rear door since I could not swerve or brake. Which sub-habits should Driver A have used to avoid this collision?

options.text: Respond, Communicate, Scan
Respond, Clear Blind Spots, Communicate
Maintain, Clear Blind Spots, Stagger
Respond, Clear Blind Spots, Stagger

questions.questionText: I (Driver A) was driving in the middle of a pack of vehicles on a one-way street. I was cut off by Driver B who swerved to avoid a vehicle door being opened in the curb lane. questions.questionText: It was raining hard. A driver on my (Driver A) right stopped for a stop sign, glanced in my direction and then pulled out from the side road just in front of me. Respond, Mirror, Communicate, Ground View
Respond, Minimum Eye Lead Time, Stagger, Scan

options.text: Control, Ground View, Stagger
Respond, Ground View, Left Centre Right
Point, Ground View, Left Centre Right
Respond, React, Left Centre Right

questions.questionText: If you are waiting to make a left turn at a traffic light, what is NOT a reason you have to check the left blind spot before turning?

options.text: To see if there is a squirrel approaching
To see if any pedestrians may be walking into the area you are going to turn through
To see if a motorcycle or other vehicle is trying to turn inside your path because they don't want to wait for you to turn
To see if any cyclists may be riding or walking their bikes into the area you are going to turn through

questions.questionText: What is the key element of the sub-habit 'Spot'?

options.text: To make sure that you and your passengers are not a problem
To make sure that everyone inside your vehicle is having a good time and has equal say in the music
To predict how other drivers are going to solve their problems on the road
To make sure you're doing everything right when you drive

questions.questionText: If you have a rear camera, do you need to worry about the sub-habit Avoid Backing? (Choose all that apply)

options.text: No, with experience and skill, there is no issue with reversing – everybody does it, and everyone else needs to pay attention when someone is backing out of a driveway or parking stall

Yes, while the back-up camera can have a great view of what is directly behind the vehicle, it is limited in its ability to see what's coming from the sides like a pedestrian or a motorcycle that are small and move quickly
No, there are no worries with this technology as many commercials continue to show how easy and safe it is to use when reversing

Yes, the back-up camera can have obstructions to the sides like farther back parked vehicles that obscure your view of what might be coming as well as bushes or snowbanks that can block the camera's view to see what might be on the sidewalk should you be backing out of a driveway

questions.questionText: What type of parking should you always try to avoid?

options.text: Backing in straight between two vehicles
Pulling through one parking stall to park in the next one facing out
Backing in straight beside one vehicle
Angle parking driving in forwards

questions.questionText: Some cities use a countdown timer to let pedestrians know how much time they have to get across an intersection before the light may change. Why not use this timer to help decide what to do when approaching a stale green traffic light?

options.text: The countdown timer does not tell what the vehicle behind you is going to do - you may be braking, anticipating the change when the driver behind is speeding up, easily leading to a collision

The green light may not change when the countdown timer reaches 0 - you could be braking at a green light for no reason when the driver behind does not expect you to brake, leading to a possible collision
Neither of these answers is correct
Both of these answers are correct

questions.questionText: Do you need to use the 'Point of No Return' if turning at an intersection with traffic lights?

options.text: Yes, at every stale green traffic light, including protected turn arrows and lights without protected turn arrows
No, it is only used at intersections that have countdown timers
No, it is only used when the 'Don't Walk' hand is on
No, it is only used when going straight

questions.questionText: Does it matter which way your wheels are facing if you are turning right and waiting for pedestrians to clear the crosswalk?

options.text: Yes, the wheels must always be facing your escape route and not facing the pedestrians
No - it only matters when you are making a left because if you get hit from behind you don't want to get knocked into the path of oncoming traffic

questions.questionText: If you are stopped at a light and there is a larger vehicle stopped behind you, is it possible to see past it when you are driving a smaller vehicle?

options.text: Yes, since usually before stopping, you can position your vehicle a little to the left or right of your lane to use your sideview mirrors to see past the large vehicle.
No, the large vehicle is too wide and hopefully, there is nothing that is going to hit that vehicle behind you to knock it into you

options.text: Doing so makes the turn into the first open lane easier

There is room to creep on the amber light to advance the turn
